info: The filing enumerates operating segments by geography and market segment, covering corporate, small business, government, and education channels across hardware, software, services, and other products.

The filing enumerates operating segment and sales‑channel classifications (Hardware, Software Products, Services, Other Products & Services) across corporate, small‑business, government, education and all‑other segments for FY 2022, each reported with a value of 140.

CDW Corp, a Fortune 500 IT solutions provider serving the US, UK and Canada, operates in roughly 150 countries with about 10,900 customer‑facing employees and positions itself as a neutral multi‑brand channel partner; as of June 28 2024 its non‑affiliate market value was $29.8 billion based on a $223.84 closing price and the company had 132.5 million shares outstanding as of February 2025.

CDW remains a leading multi‑brand IT solutions provider serving over 250,000 customers in roughly 150 countries, with a workforce of about 15,100 employees (including 10,900 customer‑facing staff). 2024 net sales fell to $20.999 billion from $21.376 billion in 2023 and $23.749 billion in 2022, with hardware accounting for 72.5% ($15.219 billion) and the UK/Canada markets contributing $2.5 billion.  The company shipped roughly 26 million units and drop‑shipment accounted for about 54% of North America sales.  Three largest vendor partners each generated $2 billion in sales.  The business continues to leverage extensive distribution centers, a broad vendor portfolio and strong human capital to drive growth despite competitive pressures.

The filing highlights CDW’s sizable global workforce of approximately 15,100 employees, with 11,500 in the U.S. and 3,600 abroad, and extensive training resources including over 20,000 on‑demand educational modules. Executive leadership ages are disclosed. The company stresses a strong, non‑union culture and robust total‑rewards programs. Key strategic risks center on reliance on major vendor partners and wholesale distributors, short‑term contracts, and potential loss of incentives, as well as competitive pressure from direct vendor sales and AI‑related reputational and compliance challenges. An ERP and broader IT transformation is slated for 2025, amid ongoing cybersecurity and system‑reliability concerns.

The company highlights extensive operational and cybersecurity risks, including challenges maintaining and integrating complex IT systems, potential data breaches from internal or third‑party vulnerabilities, and exposure to cyber‑attacks, state‑sponsored threats, and AI‑enhanced attacks. It also notes risks from acquisitions with non‑standard security controls, reliance on outsourced and offshore partners, natural disasters affecting data centers or distribution facilities, rising delivery costs, accounts‑receivable and inventory obsolescence risks, labor shortages, and the impact of macro‑economic conditions, foreign‑currency fluctuations, supply‑chain disruptions, and regulatory compliance on results and cash flow.

The company highlights extensive supply chain exposure to Asian geopolitical and trade risks, extensive legal and regulatory compliance challenges, and significant indebtedness with $5.8 billion total debt, $355 million inventory financing, $1.2 billion revolving loan capacity, and $635 million variable‑rate debt, all subject to restrictive covenants. It notes a large property footprint of 2.3 million sq ft across owned and leased sites, including two major distribution centers (513,240 sq ft and 442,400 sq ft). Cybersecurity is ISO 27001 certified with no material incidents reported, and the CISO brings over 20 years of experience. Anti‑takeover provisions and potential stock volatility are also disclosed, with lease expirations extending up to 11 years.

The Audit Committee oversees cybersecurity risk reporting, while the company operates 2.3 million sq ft of facilities (including owned centers of 513,240 sq ft and 442,400 sq ft). A quarterly cash dividend of $0.625 per share was declared and the board authorized a $750 million increase to the share‑repurchase program, adding to the $588 million remaining after December 2024; 0.8 million shares were repurchased in Q4 2024. Financially, net sales fell to $20.999 billion in 2024 from $21.376 billion in 2023, with gross profit margin steady at ~21.9% and operating income margin at 7.9%. Net income decreased modestly to $1.078 billion, and cash‑flow metrics declined, reflecting macro‑economic uncertainty and measured customer spending.

Net sales fell 1.8% to $20,998.7 million in 2024, driven by weaker demand across all segments amid economic uncertainty; gross profit margin modestly improved to 21.9% despite a $50 million drop in gross profit; operating income slipped 1.8% to $1,651.3 million, while interest expense decreased as higher cash balances generated more interest income; income tax expense rose to $357.6 million, lifting the effective tax rate to 24.9%. Segmentally, corporate sales slipped 1.4% and operating income rose 3.9% after lower compensation costs; small‑business sales fell 2.1%; public‑sector sales declined 6.8%; education and healthcare saw modest declines and gains respectively. Overall, the company highlighted continued cautious customer spending and a shift toward higher‑margin SaaS offerings.

Segment net sales fell across corporate, small business, public and other segments, with decreases ranging from $33 million to $148 million, while operating income rose in most segments due to lower compensation and expense reductions, keeping gross margins stable around 23‑20%. Non‑GAAP operating income fell to $1.95 billion, and non‑GAAP net income slipped to $1.73 billion. Net sales declined 1.8% (1.9% on a constant‑currency basis) to $21.0 billion. Free cash flow dropped to $1.15 billion, and adjusted free cash flow fell to $1.08 billion. Seasonality remains concentrated in the Public segment’s Q2‑Q3 periods.

Liquidity remains robust with a $1.2 billion revolving loan facility and $5.8 billion total unsecured debt; 2024 free cash flow fell to $1.155 billion (adjusted $1.079 billion) versus 2023, while operating cash generation declined. The company issued $1.2 billion of senior notes (two $600 million tranches) and repurchased 2.4 million shares for $500 million. Quarterly dividends were $0.620–$0.625 per share, totaling $2.485 per share in 2024, with a $0.625 dividend declared for 2025. The cash conversion cycle widened to 18 days from 17, driven by higher days sales outstanding. No material off‑balance‑sheet arrangements were reported.

Balance sheet assets and liabilities grew modestly in 2024, with current assets rising to $6.4 billion and goodwill to $4.2 billion; net sales slipped slightly to $18.5 billion while operating income and net income increased to $1.56 billion and $1.01 billion respectively. Management completed its annual goodwill impairment assessment and found no impairment. Interest‑rate and foreign‑currency risks were judged immaterial even under hypothetical rate shifts. Revenue recognition requires significant judgment for bundled contracts and variable consideration.

Auditor issued an unqualified opinion on the 2024 financial statements and internal control, highlighting a critical audit matter involving judgment in estimating total project costs for professional‑services contracts. Financial results show net sales declining to 20,998.7 million in 2024 from 21,376.0 million in 2023, with net income falling to 1,077.8 million. The balance sheet reflects lower cash and higher long‑term debt, while earnings per share decreased modestly.

Net income declined slightly in 2024 to 1077.8 million from 1104.3 million in 2023 and 1114.5 million in 2022; operating cash flow fell to 1277.3 million versus 1598.7 million a year earlier; capital expenditures decreased to 122.6 million from 148.2 million; the company repurchased 500.0 million of common stock in both 2024 and 2023 and paid dividends of 332.1 million and 321.5 million respectively; revolving credit facility borrowings generated 294.2 million in 2024 offset by equal repayments, while long‑term debt issuance added 1197.8 million; overall cash decreased by 81.0 million, leaving 507.7 million cash at year‑end.

CDW reported stable net income around $1.1B through 2023, increased its dividend per share each year to $2.485, and consistently repurchased roughly $500M of stock annually while total equity grew to $2.35B and shares outstanding declined to 132.6M; restricted cash stood at $4M at year‑end 2024.

The company measures allowance for credit loss on unbilled receivables using internal risk ratings and third‑party default rates, deeming most of these receivables low risk. Inventory is valued at lower of cost or net realizable value using FIFO with obsolescence reserves. Property and equipment are depreciated straight‑line and reviewed for impairment. Operating leases are recorded at present value using incremental borrowing rates, with short‑term leases (<12 months) exempt from right‑of‑use accounting. Goodwill is assessed annually with a qualitative test and quantitatively every three years, with testing performed in the fourth quarter. Intangible assets are amortized straight‑line and impaired based on undiscounted cash flows. Cloud‑computing implementation costs are capitalized and amortized over the hosting term. Debt issuance costs are capitalized and amortized. Fair value measurements follow the three‑level hierarchy. Revenue is recognized on a gross basis when the company is the principal (e.g., hardware, many software licenses) and on a net basis when acting as an agent (e.g., certain software assurances, vendor‑partner services). Variable considerations such as rebates and returns are estimated at contract inception, and contract assets and liabilities are recorded accordingly.

The company highlights variable consideration estimation risks, modest advertising spend growth to $218 million in 2024, and the acquisition of Mission Cloud Services for $330 million which added $218 million of goodwill and $139 million of other intangibles. Accounts receivable rose to $6.059 billion in 2024 with $477 million of receivables sold, while the allowance for credit losses increased to $47.4 million. Contract assets fell to $97.1 million and liabilities to $522.3 million, with revenue recognized from contract liabilities decreasing to $315 million. Remaining performance obligations total $220.8 million across future periods. Property and equipment net decreased to $192 million, with disposals of $37 million and depreciation expense of $53 million in 2024.

The company recorded PPE disposals of $37M, $56M and $7M in 2024‑2022 and depreciation expenses of $53M, $52M and $58M for the same years. Goodwill increased to $4.62B in 2024 with no impairment identified, while intangible assets saw disposals of $155M, $33M and $8M and amortization of $222M, $219M and $233M. Future intangible amortization is projected at $1.36B through 2029 and beyond. Inventory‑financing obligations stood at $355M (2024) versus $431M (2023); the firm remains covenant‑compliant, holds $5.61B of long‑term debt (2024) and can draw an additional $1.2B under its revolving facility, which has $356M reserved for floor‑plan financing. Senior notes outstanding total $4.98B (2024) with rates ranging from 2.67% to 5.55% across maturities.

Company remains covenant compliant and retains $1.2 billion borrowing capacity on its revolving loan, with $356 million set aside for floorplan financing. In August 2024 it issued $1.2 billion of senior notes (5.10% due 2030 and 5.55% due 2034) and concurrently repurchased $780 million of existing 5.5% and 4.125% notes, later redeeming the remaining $184 million 5.5% notes. Debt maturities total $5.88 billion through 2029 with $2.2 billion beyond. Fair value of long‑term debt is $5.60 billion versus a carrying amount of $5.88 billion. The company maintains $400 million of interest‑rate collar notional and executed $600 million of treasury locks tied to the new notes. Short‑term investments total $214 million. Income tax expense for 2024 was $357.6 million, reflecting $1.31 billion domestic and $123 million foreign taxes.

Deferred tax assets rose modestly and net deferred tax liabilities fell slightly, while operating lease liabilities decreased as lease costs fell to $60 million. The company repurchased 2.4 million shares for $500 million and increased its share‑repurchase authorization by $750 million, leaving about $588 million remaining. Equity‑based compensation expense dropped sharply to $64.7 million. Unrecognized tax benefits total $20 million with a potential $16 million tax gain. The firm retains $88 million of indefinite net operating loss carryforwards and $17 million of tax credit carryforwards. The 2021 LTIP has 6.2 million shares available out of a 22.1 million cap, and stock‑option fair values rose to $76.21.

The company reported substantial equity compensation activity in 2024, with 2.77 million stock options outstanding at year-end and a weighted-average exercise price of $134.15, and an aggregate intrinsic value of $132.3 million. RSU grants totaled 328,768 units at a fair value of $203.24, and vested RSUs contributed $37 million of fair value. PSU grants of 199,174 units had a fair value of $224.53, with $42 million vested. Diluted shares increased to 135.2 million, reflecting a modest dilutive effect from equity awards. Profit-sharing expense rose to $27 million. Ongoing legal matters include a DOJ False Claims Act inquiry, though no material loss is currently expected.

Segment reporting shows total net sales decreasing from $21.376B in 2023 to $20.999B in 2024, with the corporate segment remaining the largest contributor. Gross profit and operating income also slipped slightly year‑over‑year, while depreciation and amortization expense fell modestly. The company allocates logistics costs based on net sales and centralizes headquarters functions, which recorded a negative operating income in both 2023 and 2024.

The 2024 financial note shows total net sales of $20,998.7 million, with $18,456.9 million generated in the United States and $2,541.8 million in the Rest of World. Revenue is split between principal‑transfer sales ($17,973.0 million) and agent‑transfer sales ($1,607.6 million), with additional over‑time principal sales of $1,418.1 million. Hardware contributed the largest portion of sales (US $6,015.5 million, total $15,219.1 million).

The company reported total net sales of 21376.0 million for 2023, driven largely by United States sales (18754.9 million) and a hardware focus (15702.6 million). Sales were primarily recognized at a point in time where CDW acted as principal (18512.9 million), with smaller portions recognized as an agent (1521.8 million) or over time (1341.3 million). Corporate customers contributed the bulk of revenue (8960.8 million), followed by public (8305.7 million) and other segments (2553.5 million).

In 2022 CDW recorded total net sales of $23.7 billion, with the United States contributing about $20.8 billion (roughly 87% of sales). Hardware accounted for the bulk of revenue ($18.1B), followed by software ($3.7B), services ($1.8B) and other items ($0.13B). The corporate channel was the largest sales segment ($10.35B), with notable contributions from education, government, healthcare and small‑business segments. Most revenue was recognized at a point in time where CDW acted as principal ($21.0B), while a smaller portion ($1.4B) was recognized where CDW was an agent.

Net sales declined to $20.9987 billion in 2024 from $21.3760 billion in 2023 and $23.7487 billion in 2022, with hardware comprising roughly 72% of sales. Software, services and other categories contributed modest shares, while internal controls were deemed effective with no material changes or auditor disagreements.
The filing provides an extensive list of exhibits detailing corporate charter, bylaws and agreements for CDW and its subsidiaries, with links to prior filings and references.

The filing lists numerous supplemental indentures and credit agreements for CDW, documenting multiple senior notes issued at varying interest rates (ranging from 2.670% to 5.550%) and recent amendments to credit facilities, highlighting the company’s ongoing debt financing activities and reliance on U.S. Bank as trustee.

The filing enumerates a range of exhibits covering indemnification agreements, senior management incentive plans, long‑term incentive plans, stock purchase and award agreements, and other corporate governance documents, and provides the signature page where Chair, President and CEO Christine A. Leahy and other officers and directors signed the report on February 21, 2025.
